reviewText:
Limbo is a great indie game.

You are thrown into the game completely clueless about the plot and you are not briefed about the character's background, environment or any other aspect of the game. Throughout gameplay of Limbo, you follow along the experiences of a little boy in which you play as. You are presented with some challenging obstacles in which you learn many things from along with the character through your mistakes and the use of the method of trial and error. The game and levels are cleverly designed and though the obstacles are challenging to an extent, I have never found them to be overwhelmingly frustrating but in fact, I have found them to be rather enjoyable.

The mood through the use of simple music and an unique artistic style involving dark monotonal colours is great at immersing the player into the scene. You begin to develop an attachment with character throughout the game.The physics/movement is applaudable, the character control is smooth and the controls are simple and easy to use.

This game is an amazing piece of work. It is definitely worth the price. I have no regrets buying this game and I highly recommend this game to those considering to purchase and all of those who have not purchased this game. What are you waiting for?! :)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I'd say this is one of those games you either love or hate. Personally, I loved it. I can't, however, see any reason whatsoever to spend $10 on this game. It's dark and tricky but the length of gameplay kills the price tag. Steam has me registered with 111 minutes on Limbo. I'd say a good 30 minutes of that, if not more, was registered while I was paused, doing things around the house. When I got to the end, I figured I had just completed the first chapter. Nope, no more story. If you've played the demo and like it then wait for it to go on sale. I'd say $3 is reasonable but I can't in good conscience recommend you spend any more than that on it.

reviewText:
I bought Limbo when it was on sale like maybe a year ago and didnt play it too much because, as its always, there were many other games to play, but the first thing i can say, is that the game is worth every cent, even if you buy it for 10 Dollar or whatever.
Limbo has on of the best and most scary atmospheres in indie games i've ever seen.
Although it's only 2D and you don't get to know the boy really well, you learn to feel his feelings and fear his fears, like huge and gross monster-spiders and stuff like this.
Furthermore, it's has some nice puzzle elements, which makes it one of the best indie games i've played so far.

So as a conclusion, i strongly recommend the game to everyone who likes games with great atmospheres and puzzle elements.

reviewText:
This game is very unusual. It's a 2D platformer/puzzle game, with its most striking feature being that its completely black 'n white. It has no music and barely any sound.
It's pretty short, can be even completed in one sitting. Pratically no replay value.
The story (yes there's a story) and the setting make this game very melancholic, even depressing to some.
Even while taking these things in consideration, i have to recommend LIMBO to any real gamer, because this is a beautiful game, and if someone states videogames cant be art, this proves them wrong.

reviewText:
I would rate this a solid 8/10.

I loved the rich tone that is set from the very beginning. This game is fantastically creepy and horrifying yet extremely intriguing. Who are you? Where are you? Why are you there? LIMBO is minimal in design and story, but it does not disappoint. The game itself is gorgeous. The puzzles are just challenging enough that you get frustrated but feel accomplished when you figure it out. I killed myself in ways I didn't even know were possible.

My only gripe is the ending, but I think everyone interpretates it differently. Regardless, well worth your time if you enjoy unique puzzle platformers and games that have a strong ambiance.

reviewText:
Limbo is an Indie platform  melancholic game that extends beyond the casual indie games, when you first start it you dont see much talk arround the plot, in fact I had to see the reviews so I could find out what the game was about.
Apparently, its about a boy who goes for a quest after his sister who fell  in the Limbo.
All of the game is played on a grey, white and black environment so that we could get that a sad, creepy, melancholic visual experience.
The fact is that when we reach a certain level we get bored with all thoose environments.
The game offers us some great puzzle/platform challenges, but also gives us a slow and boring gameplay  which ruins all the emotion.
I would recommend this game for those who truly love indie games, and for those who are looking for a different type of game.
It wasn't execlly money well spent, actually, but since it was made by an independent developer, it's acceptable.
Limbo had excelent scores on Metacritic and IGN, I think you should check some other reviews and watch some gameplays (without spoiler) before you buy the game.

reviewText:
REVIEW: LIMBO

Limbo is one of those games I had heard of, but never really put on the to-do list. It was only thanks to the generosity of a friend on Steam that I gained a copy to try and complete. But I haven’t been a fan of platformer games for some time, so would I enjoy Limbo?

In a mysterious, monochrome world, a boy awakens in a dark forest. He sets out in search of his sister. But in his way are the various denizens of this world, from giant spiders to parasitic worms, and even other kids…

There are four words that sum up Limbo: dark, artistic, minimalistic, and frustrating. Easily, the best part of the game is the presentation. It’s dark and moody, the graphics are just right for the macabre style, and the whole atmosphere is enhanced by a dark and appropriate soundtrack. Music and sound effects contribute to an eerie and intimidating atmosphere. It’s like Silent Hill, but, if anything, even darker. While at first glance it appears to be a kid’s game, it is anything but. I dunno what the rating is, but parents, THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS. This is a violent and dark game. Bleakly beautiful and beautifully bleak, but definitely not for kids.

The gameplay is another matter entirely. It is hard, even by the gold standard of Nintendo platformers. The gameplay consists of avoiding death and figuring out how to progress by trial and error, or as the publishers once called it, ‘trial and death’. And you will die. A lot. In manifold gruesome fashions. But figuring out how to get by the latest obstacles or adversaries will give you a feeling of accomplishment. Unfortunately, I tended to get more frustrated than feeling like I accomplished anything meaningful.

The game comes across as the illegitimate offspring of Silent Hill and Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysey (which, incidentally, was recently re-released on Steam). While the difficulty feels right for such a game, I just wish it wasn’t quite so hard. And the payoff in the minimalist story doesn’t quite work.

That being said, Limbo is pretty good. I like it mainly for the presentation more than the gameplay, but the gameplay itself has its own charms. It’s just a touch too hard for my liking…

RATING: ***½

reviewText:
Long story short: a great puzzle platformer!
Details:
The graphics style with its only two colors (black and white, and its mixing gray) is causing a very nice oppressive atmosphere. All animations are very detailed and smooth, in fact you can only see silhouettes. Depth is created with blur.
Level transitions are fluent, no loading screens, which creates a nostalgic feeling. You think you can always go back from where you came from. In Fact you can't, as some geographical obstacles block the way back.
Even though the main purpose of this game is to solve puzzles, which are using physics and differ in grade of difficulty, LIMBO also has a profound background story or at least events.
First you have to defend yourself against a spider, and cut of three of its legs. Then it's fleeing, but catches you later on a webbed floor. As you escape the spider is following you again, and you head it to a small village. The people are not delighted of course, as the spider is killing them. So they also try to kill you, in return you have to kill them. Afterwards you also manage to escape from the spider, which is so hurt, that only one leg is left. To get further, you have to tear out also the last leg, and use the spider's body.
Later you see that the people of the village are sometimes controlled by a worm, which causes them to walk into water and to drown. Again you have to use a dead body to complete your journey.
Several times you try to reach a girl, but you are led away by a worm or cannot reach her.
All these incidents are disturbing in some kind and thought-provoking.

It's a lot of fun to get all hidden eggs, and find the hidden level.
I completed the game on Linux, it was running perfect, even the XBox 360 controller rumbled.

reviewText:
Deliciously cruel; gorgeously morbid; compellingly unforgiving and unfair.

A long-time classic of the indie scene and nigh-unanimously loved for the dark beauty it achieves with its simple noir style. It's a short game (about four hours), and it is a must-have for any fan of artistic games, gruesome puzzles, or dark platformers. If you're not good with puzzles and/or platformers, but still want to experience the game's much-praised atmosphere, do know that that checkpoints are very frequent, so dying won't put you too far back. And you will die, often. Should you find yourself truly stuck, the Steam community also has helpful guides that can get you through.

5/5 Creepy Boy-Thumbs Up. Buy this game and share in a child's journey through pitiless Limbo.

reviewText:
What can I say about Limbo that has not already been said.  It Dark, disturbing at points, atmospheric, beautiful and enchanting.  It is easy to play but engaging at all times, presents puzzles to you but not obviously as a puzzle.  The main character is childlike but the world is harsh.  The story is subtle but evolves perfectly as the play and leaves you with questions.
This game should not be remade, changed or even have a sequel. It stands on its own in many respects and just is.
If it was £30 it should still be bought and played, just so that you can say you were there when it happened. I have been playing games since pong and there are many games that I am proud to be able to say I was part of at the time of their breakthrough.  Limbo is one such game.  So much so that I have ordered the special edition on Amazon, just because I want to be able to hand it to my children when the time is right.

reviewText: Limbo is a puzzle platformer that will keep you on your toes until the very end as you regularly encounter unfamiliar obstacles.  The controls are minimal and the puzzles aren't terribly difficult to solve, making the game inviting for people of all ages.  The game is masterfully designed and animated.  From the very beginning you will feel immersed in the strange dark world of Limbo.  The story is not very long, and there is not much replayability unless you want to go for all of the achievements.  Keeping this in mind, Limbo remains one of the best indie games on the market.  I highly recommend adding it to your collection.

reviewText: LIMBO is the perfect example of how a very simple game can reach the point of being a work of art. Its minimalistic approach works to its advantage, bringing out a silent, gloomy atmosphere that adds a tone of mystery. The controls are pretty basic, the physics is magnificent and the difficulty curve is just right. The best thing about the game would probably be that the puzzles you encounter dont require raw skill like in most platformers, but most of the times, if something you do doesn't work, you need to take a different approach. You will, nevertheless, die a lot, but the save points are so frequent that you will not be frustrated at all. Perhaps LIMBO's greatest shortcoming is its short duration, but its quality definitely makes up for it.

reviewText:
Limbo is a beautiful, atmospheric puzzle platformer with a hard edge. What story it has is largely implicit—the game contains no dialogue. You simply wake in a dark wood, apparently a child, and set off to explore the dingy place in which you find yourself. But the genre of the game is certainly horror, though without most of the usual tropes. You are fragile—easily hurt, unable to swim, essentially defenseless—in a hostile and trap-ridden place. You will die many times. And the game does not divert your gaze from your death but rather renders each different mode of your demise in somewhat disturbing detail.

The artistic style of the game simultaneously keeps this from being too macabre and contributes greatly to the eerie atmosphere. The game's graphics are entirely silhouettes in shades of grey. Yet the landscapes and objects feel very detailed. Beautifully done lighting effects give the impression of a layered world mostly in shadow. All this makes for a beautiful noir environment well worth admiration in its own right. This game is more immersive with black and white outlines than much I’ve played that had expensive 3D-graphics.

A subtler strength of the game is the way its physics feel naturalistic—you are acutely aware of the weight of objects and the force of gravity.  I doubt that the game’s engine is particularly remarkable in this regard, it’s an aesthetic effect. Great attention has been paid to the visual details of motion. But I think it also comes from player movement: in many games you play as a character with outsized physical capabilities. Even in shooters and platformers where such isn’t part of the story your movements are subtly superhuman (think of the lateral jumping featured in most platformers). Not here. Here you have a painfully tiny lateral jump and a rather slow top speed. Here objects don’t just slide easily into place but are dragged only with great effort.

The largest complaint I had with LIMBO was that it was too short. Though the puzzles were good, and admirably varied, not too many were very difficult. If one is adept at this sort of thing one could easily complete the game in just a few hours. They are an excellent few hours though. The puzzles are crisp, things to be grasped, not just fiddled with. For a little while LIMBO takes you to an unsettling, engrossing otherworld. And I’d very much like to visit again.

reviewText:
LIMBO is an indie/adventure puzzle-platform video game, the first released title brought to us by the Danish developers Playdead. While the game itself was first released in July 2010 as an exclusive title on the Xbox Live Arcade, Playdead decided to re-release the game on other platforms after the Xbox exclusivity had ended. This meant that PS3 and PC players could get their hands on this amazing title after all. The developers never stopped there as they continued to release the game on other platforms such as OS X and Linux in 2012 and eventually even for the PS Vita and iOS in 2013. By continuously expanding the platforms this game can run on, the developers show us that they are proud of their first title and rightfully so.

Settings

You wake up as a nameless boy, who I named George, in the middle of a dark and eerily forest. There is no explanation to how this boy got here, nor what his tasks are, so the start of the journey leaves you with an infinite amount of questions. If you don’t feel sorry for this young boy at first, you will certainly feel more pity towards this adolescent adventurer as the story advances when he comes across human characters who would rather have him dead then be helpful or died of unexplainable reasons. Other creatures are also lurking in the forest, such as giant spiders who enjoy spiking this poor boy with their legs. The end has us bringing the boy to a girl, presumably his missing sister when the game abruptly ends leaving us with yet more questions.

Gameplay

Since LIMBO is a 2D platform video game, you can only steer the boy left or right, jump up, climb on ledges and up or down ladders and ropes. There is also an action-button where you can push or pull objects which are mostly part of a puzzle. Those who find more joy by playing with controllers are in luck since the Xbox Controller works perfectly. The graphics are dark and grayscale to provide more depth in the scenery. The sounds are kept at minimal, which leaves you with a setting that is both stunning and alarming. If your spider-senses aren’t tingling with this game, you sure are one hell of a cold-blooded player. At some point you may find yourself laughing hysterically, if you are evil-kindred that is, when you hear the splash-sounds the game creates when you’ve killed a creature or unkind humans. Since you will not always understand what you need to do to solve a puzzle, numerous amounts of deaths is inevitable. These horrifying deaths are accompanied with gruesome sounds and images of the boy being dismembered or beheaded. As if the creepiness of the settings wasn’t enough to cause panic in my mind.

Final conclusion

Overall this game has left me amazed with the fact that such a simple design and story can leave me with such an eerie feeling. It may be an older game but I would certainly recommend it for any player who enjoys puzzles and platform games.

This review can also be found on nearlyenoughdice.com

reviewText: LIMBO is, like Braid or Bastion, one of the rare games which perfectly mix game and art. (Unlike e.g. Tale of Tales Games' work or The Void, which is pretty much interactive art instead of an actual game, what can be good, too!) This game is beautifull yet somehow horrific, you are a helpless little boy and look for your sister in Limbo. That's all of story that there is but there is nothing more necessary. Everything else is open to interpretation.\nIf you like games, which are not just mindless fun blasting enemies away but also let you think about what you are doing and why, this may be the perfect choice for you, mixed with a great art style!\nFor me, LIMBO represents one of the few titles, I'd give a 10/10 score!

reviewText:
Now, my lovely people who are spending their valuable time reading this rather mediocre review of a first-rate game, hello and welcome.

LIMBO deserves a far-greater write up than what I have to offer, but the thought counts, amiright? Hopefully I'm right. For the benefit of the existence of this fangirl review, we'll say I am.

Where to begin? If I had a way to shrink this game down to fit into a locket, I would. It would lie near my excitable heart alongside SSX 3. SSX 3! Need this review say any more? After this one last thought, no.

I'm smitten for SSX 3. I have a particularly strong leaning towards LIMBO.
I adore them both.

They're my yin and yang of games: alone they're great, but with both in my life, they balance out my love.

STRONGLY RECOMMENDED

reviewText:
REVIEW: LIMBO

Limbo is one of those games I had heard of, but never really put on the to-do list. It was only thanks to the generosity of a friend on Steam that I gained a copy to try and complete. But I haven’t been a fan of platformer games for some time, so would I enjoy Limbo?

In a mysterious, monochrome world, a boy awakens in a dark forest. He sets out in search of his sister. But in his way are the various denizens of this world, from giant spiders to parasitic worms, and even other kids…

There are four words that sum up Limbo: dark, artistic, minimalistic, and frustrating. Easily, the best part of the game is the presentation. It’s dark and moody, the graphics are just right for the macabre style, and the whole atmosphere is enhanced by a dark and appropriate soundtrack. Music and sound effects contribute to an eerie and intimidating atmosphere. It’s like Silent Hill, but, if anything, even darker. While at first glance it appears to be a kid’s game, it is anything but. I dunno what the rating is, but parents, THIS IS NOT FOR KIDS. This is a violent and dark game. Bleakly beautiful and beautifully bleak, but definitely not for kids.

The gameplay is another matter entirely. It is hard, even by the gold standard of Nintendo platformers. The gameplay consists of avoiding death and figuring out how to progress by trial and error, or as the publishers once called it, ‘trial and death’. And you will die. A lot. In manifold gruesome fashions. But figuring out how to get by the latest obstacles or adversaries will give you a feeling of accomplishment. Unfortunately, I tended to get more frustrated than feeling like I accomplished anything meaningful.

The game comes across as the illegitimate offspring of Silent Hill and Oddworld: Abe’s Oddysey (which, incidentally, was recently re-released on Steam). While the difficulty feels right for such a game, I just wish it wasn’t quite so hard. And the payoff in the minimalist story doesn’t quite work.

That being said, Limbo is pretty good. I like it mainly for the presentation more than the gameplay, but the gameplay itself has its own charms. It’s just a touch too hard for my liking…

RATING: ***½

reviewText:
I would rate this a solid 8/10.

I loved the rich tone that is set from the very beginning. This game is fantastically creepy and horrifying yet extremely intriguing. Who are you? Where are you? Why are you there? LIMBO is minimal in design and story, but it does not disappoint. The game itself is gorgeous. The puzzles are just challenging enough that you get frustrated but feel accomplished when you figure it out. I killed myself in ways I didn't even know were possible.

My only gripe is the ending, but I think everyone interpretates it differently. Regardless, well worth your time if you enjoy unique puzzle platformers and games that have a strong ambiance.

reviewText: LIMBO is the perfect example of how a very simple game can reach the point of being a work of art. Its minimalistic approach works to its advantage, bringing out a silent, gloomy atmosphere that adds a tone of mystery. The controls are pretty basic, the physics is magnificent and the difficulty curve is just right. The best thing about the game would probably be that the puzzles you encounter dont require raw skill like in most platformers, but most of the times, if something you do doesn't work, you need to take a different approach. You will, nevertheless, die a lot, but the save points are so frequent that you will not be frustrated at all. Perhaps LIMBO's greatest shortcoming is its short duration, but its quality definitely makes up for it.

reviewText:
LIMBO is an indie/adventure puzzle-platform video game, the first released title brought to us by the Danish developers Playdead. While the game itself was first released in July 2010 as an exclusive title on the Xbox Live Arcade, Playdead decided to re-release the game on other platforms after the Xbox exclusivity had ended. This meant that PS3 and PC players could get their hands on this amazing title after all. The developers never stopped there as they continued to release the game on other platforms such as OS X and Linux in 2012 and eventually even for the PS Vita and iOS in 2013. By continuously expanding the platforms this game can run on, the developers show us that they are proud of their first title and rightfully so.

Settings

You wake up as a nameless boy, who I named George, in the middle of a dark and eerily forest. There is no explanation to how this boy got here, nor what his tasks are, so the start of the journey leaves you with an infinite amount of questions. If you don’t feel sorry for this young boy at first, you will certainly feel more pity towards this adolescent adventurer as the story advances when he comes across human characters who would rather have him dead then be helpful or died of unexplainable reasons. Other creatures are also lurking in the forest, such as giant spiders who enjoy spiking this poor boy with their legs. The end has us bringing the boy to a girl, presumably his missing sister when the game abruptly ends leaving us with yet more questions.

Gameplay

Since LIMBO is a 2D platform video game, you can only steer the boy left or right, jump up, climb on ledges and up or down ladders and ropes. There is also an action-button where you can push or pull objects which are mostly part of a puzzle. Those who find more joy by playing with controllers are in luck since the Xbox Controller works perfectly. The graphics are dark and grayscale to provide more depth in the scenery. The sounds are kept at minimal, which leaves you with a setting that is both stunning and alarming. If your spider-senses aren’t tingling with this game, you sure are one hell of a cold-blooded player. At some point you may find yourself laughing hysterically, if you are evil-kindred that is, when you hear the splash-sounds the game creates when you’ve killed a creature or unkind humans. Since you will not always understand what you need to do to solve a puzzle, numerous amounts of deaths is inevitable. These horrifying deaths are accompanied with gruesome sounds and images of the boy being dismembered or beheaded. As if the creepiness of the settings wasn’t enough to cause panic in my mind.

Final conclusion

Overall this game has left me amazed with the fact that such a simple design and story can leave me with such an eerie feeling. It may be an older game but I would certainly recommend it for any player who enjoys puzzles and platform games.

This review can also be found on nearlyenoughdice.com

reviewText: Limbo is a puzzle platformer that will keep you on your toes until the very end as you regularly encounter unfamiliar obstacles.  The controls are minimal and the puzzles aren't terribly difficult to solve, making the game inviting for people of all ages.  The game is masterfully designed and animated.  From the very beginning you will feel immersed in the strange dark world of Limbo.  The story is not very long, and there is not much replayability unless you want to go for all of the achievements.  Keeping this in mind, Limbo remains one of the best indie games on the market.  I highly recommend adding it to your collection.

reviewText: LIMBO is, like Braid or Bastion, one of the rare games which perfectly mix game and art. (Unlike e.g. Tale of Tales Games' work or The Void, which is pretty much interactive art instead of an actual game, what can be good, too!) This game is beautifull yet somehow horrific, you are a helpless little boy and look for your sister in Limbo. That's all of story that there is but there is nothing more necessary. Everything else is open to interpretation.\nIf you like games, which are not just mindless fun blasting enemies away but also let you think about what you are doing and why, this may be the perfect choice for you, mixed with a great art style!\nFor me, LIMBO represents one of the few titles, I'd give a 10/10 score!

reviewText:
Long story short: a great puzzle platformer!
Details:
The graphics style with its only two colors (black and white, and its mixing gray) is causing a very nice oppressive atmosphere. All animations are very detailed and smooth, in fact you can only see silhouettes. Depth is created with blur.
Level transitions are fluent, no loading screens, which creates a nostalgic feeling. You think you can always go back from where you came from. In Fact you can't, as some geographical obstacles block the way back.
Even though the main purpose of this game is to solve puzzles, which are using physics and differ in grade of difficulty, LIMBO also has a profound background story or at least events.
First you have to defend yourself against a spider, and cut of three of its legs. Then it's fleeing, but catches you later on a webbed floor. As you escape the spider is following you again, and you head it to a small village. The people are not delighted of course, as the spider is killing them. So they also try to kill you, in return you have to kill them. Afterwards you also manage to escape from the spider, which is so hurt, that only one leg is left. To get further, you have to tear out also the last leg, and use the spider's body.
Later you see that the people of the village are sometimes controlled by a worm, which causes them to walk into water and to drown. Again you have to use a dead body to complete your journey.
Several times you try to reach a girl, but you are led away by a worm or cannot reach her.
All these incidents are disturbing in some kind and thought-provoking.

It's a lot of fun to get all hidden eggs, and find the hidden level.
I completed the game on Linux, it was running perfect, even the XBox 360 controller rumbled.

reviewText: Simply amazing 2D platformer with a film noir/german expressionist art style and challenging, puzzle-solving gameplay. Despite the seeming simplicity of the graphics, it's one of the most visually stunning games I've ever played. The premise and story of the game is mysterious and deliberately ambiguous, tantalising you all the time with intriguing and often disturbing developments which make you question what you're seeing. The ending is one of the most intriguing I've ever seen in a game; even days after I finished it I was still thinking about it. LIMBO is exciting, moving and mysterious at the same time. It is an experience more akin to a movie and leaves a lasting impression. If you ever wondered whether games could be considered art then here's your answer. They can...

reviewText:
Want something to exercise your brains? Try Limbo.

The game is very atmospheric puzzle/plat-former game. I found it to be very enjoyable for the most part but some parts were frustrating. It's not that the puzzles were hard, most of it made sense and you will find solutions easily. Performing it was the difficult part, like jumping on a very specific spot and a few millimeters off and you will fail. Reminds of the old Famicom/NES games.

It doesn't have any deep story. You woke up in a forest and while exploring you found out that everyone and everything was out there to kill you so your main goal was to escape. The ending was one of those that left it for the players to decide it's meaning. You will play Limbo mainly for its puzzles.

reviewText: An noir indie game that's definitely worth playing. The game excels in a minimalistic design, both in arts and music, that conveys an eerie and curious feeling to the player. There is a story, told in a subtle way through the puzzles and challenges the boy meets along the adventure. I know it's strange, but somehow I feel an emotion of love and comfort radiating from the storytelling. Finally, the puzzles are unique and interesting, but there is only one way to solve them, so there's no replay value (unless you want to experience the atmosphere of the game again, which is highly possible).\n\nA rare indie gem for me. Highly recommended.

reviewText:
LIMBO is an indie/adventure puzzle-platform video game, the first released title brought to us by the Danish developers Playdead. While the game itself was first released in July 2010 as an exclusive title on the Xbox Live Arcade, Playdead decided to re-release the game on other platforms after the Xbox exclusivity had ended. This meant that PS3 and PC players could get their hands on this amazing title after all. The developers never stopped there as they continued to release the game on other platforms such as OS X and Linux in 2012 and eventually even for the PS Vita and iOS in 2013. By continuously expanding the platforms this game can run on, the developers show us that they are proud of their first title and rightfully so.

Settings

You wake up as a nameless boy, who I named George, in the middle of a dark and eerily forest. There is no explanation to how this boy got here, nor what his tasks are, so the start of the journey leaves you with an infinite amount of questions. If you don’t feel sorry for this young boy at first, you will certainly feel more pity towards this adolescent adventurer as the story advances when he comes across human characters who would rather have him dead then be helpful or died of unexplainable reasons. Other creatures are also lurking in the forest, such as giant spiders who enjoy spiking this poor boy with their legs. The end has us bringing the boy to a girl, presumably his missing sister when the game abruptly ends leaving us with yet more questions.

Gameplay

Since LIMBO is a 2D platform video game, you can only steer the boy left or right, jump up, climb on ledges and up or down ladders and ropes. There is also an action-button where you can push or pull objects which are mostly part of a puzzle. Those who find more joy by playing with controllers are in luck since the Xbox Controller works perfectly. The graphics are dark and grayscale to provide more depth in the scenery. The sounds are kept at minimal, which leaves you with a setting that is both stunning and alarming. If your spider-senses aren’t tingling with this game, you sure are one hell of a cold-blooded player. At some point you may find yourself laughing hysterically, if you are evil-kindred that is, when you hear the splash-sounds the game creates when you’ve killed a creature or unkind humans. Since you will not always understand what you need to do to solve a puzzle, numerous amounts of deaths is inevitable. These horrifying deaths are accompanied with gruesome sounds and images of the boy being dismembered or beheaded. As if the creepiness of the settings wasn’t enough to cause panic in my mind.

Final conclusion

Overall this game has left me amazed with the fact that such a simple design and story can leave me with such an eerie feeling. It may be an older game but I would certainly recommend it for any player who enjoys puzzles and platform games.

This review can also be found on nearlyenoughdice.com

reviewText:
A beautiful, short platformer. Although it only uses a simple dark style, this creates a very special and unique atmosphere that is hardly ever seen in video games. Simply put, the artwork of the game is just awesome and I’m surprised at how much can be achieved just by using silhouettes. Playing through Limbo felt like discovering a work of art. Its puzzles are sometimes challenging, specially towards the end, but they don’t really become annoying at any point. The music is fitting, but what I liked the most is how well silence is used throughout the game. It really makes you feel lonely and lost. The biggest highlight of the game is, however, the appearance of the spider. Just seeing the way it moves sends shivers down my spine. It’s the kind of stuff that would have given me nightmares back in the day. Definitely one of the scariest and creepiest enemies in video games ever. Seriously, kill that thing with fire and bury it as deep as you can.


And last we've got the story". Yeah… well

reviewText:
Deliciously cruel; gorgeously morbid; compellingly unforgiving and unfair.

A long-time classic of the indie scene and nigh-unanimously loved for the dark beauty it achieves with its simple noir style. It's a short game (about four hours), and it is a must-have for any fan of artistic games, gruesome puzzles, or dark platformers. If you're not good with puzzles and/or platformers, but still want to experience the game's much-praised atmosphere, do know that that checkpoints are very frequent, so dying won't put you too far back. And you will die, often. Should you find yourself truly stuck, the Steam community also has helpful guides that can get you through.

5/5 Creepy Boy-Thumbs Up. Buy this game and share in a child's journey through pitiless Limbo.

reviewText:
Limbo is a beautiful, atmospheric puzzle platformer with a hard edge. What story it has is largely implicit—the game contains no dialogue. You simply wake in a dark wood, apparently a child, and set off to explore the dingy place in which you find yourself. But the genre of the game is certainly horror, though without most of the usual tropes. You are fragile—easily hurt, unable to swim, essentially defenseless—in a hostile and trap-ridden place. You will die many times. And the game does not divert your gaze from your death but rather renders each different mode of your demise in somewhat disturbing detail.

The artistic style of the game simultaneously keeps this from being too macabre and contributes greatly to the eerie atmosphere. The game's graphics are entirely silhouettes in shades of grey. Yet the landscapes and objects feel very detailed. Beautifully done lighting effects give the impression of a layered world mostly in shadow. All this makes for a beautiful noir environment well worth admiration in its own right. This game is more immersive with black and white outlines than much I’ve played that had expensive 3D-graphics.

A subtler strength of the game is the way its physics feel naturalistic—you are acutely aware of the weight of objects and the force of gravity.  I doubt that the game’s engine is particularly remarkable in this regard, it’s an aesthetic effect. Great attention has been paid to the visual details of motion. But I think it also comes from player movement: in many games you play as a character with outsized physical capabilities. Even in shooters and platformers where such isn’t part of the story your movements are subtly superhuman (think of the lateral jumping featured in most platformers). Not here. Here you have a painfully tiny lateral jump and a rather slow top speed. Here objects don’t just slide easily into place but are dragged only with great effort.

The largest complaint I had with LIMBO was that it was too short. Though the puzzles were good, and admirably varied, not too many were very difficult. If one is adept at this sort of thing one could easily complete the game in just a few hours. They are an excellent few hours though. The puzzles are crisp, things to be grasped, not just fiddled with. For a little while LIMBO takes you to an unsettling, engrossing otherworld. And I’d very much like to visit again.

reviewText:
Play this game they said...
It's not all that hard, they said...

Seriously, I found this game to be a challenge at times on the surface, although the mechanics are very easy to understand (but harder to finesse in actual play) It's very good fun, very intellectual, and it has dark elements to it that really make it a sort of creepy setting; kind of a new breed of post-apocalyptic setting in which the player uses no actual weapons (guns, melee etc, not counting traps) and must think through their actions before following through. Great game, and the challenge makes it all the more inticing.

reviewText: Property Rating Explanation Graphics 7 The game is presented in a black and white style, which is very eerie and haunting. Gameplay 8.5 The gameplay is the classic 2D sidescroller with platforming elements, many easy to medium difficulty puzzles. Beware, you will die a lot Multiplayer N/A Single-player only. Story 9.5 You are a boy who wakes up in a lonely world made up only of black, white, and shades of gray and trying to escape all sorts of dangers in this unforgiving black and white world. Sound-Music 8 The soundtrack is ace, surprisingly good but depressing ambient music adding to the whole black and white mood. Optimization 9 Optimization is great, this game can run even on the more weak laptops without any problems. Cons N/A This game is very short, maybe 2-3 hours long. Also sometimes is really hard and unforgiving. Overall 9 A brilliant indie platformer, buy it and play it. It will stay forever in you.

reviewText:

If you value quality over long playtime, buy Limbo.

reviewText:
It's already a classic.
The first time I ran the game was just to take a look at it, since it was late.
Then I got hooked. I couldn't stop myself from playing it and I left the computer only after completed all chapters.

Throughout the game there are such unique situations and the gameplay is so well made.
Despite the lack of an well defined storyline and conclusion, everything helps the gamer to come up with some interpretation about what's going on (the visual, the soundtrack (that's simply wonderful), the clues). Yet, that can bother some people who prefer concrete answers.
After complete the game, you may find yourself searching about it's ending (that's no less than admirable imo), that intrigues a lot of people and offers different interpretations.

This game is masterpiece and it's not just recommended, it's a must play for any one.

reviewText: LIMBO is one of those games you don't play when you're overly happy. However, it's an overall amazing game whose strength is in it's somber and brooding atmosphere and simplicity. reviewText:
LIMBO is a fantastic atmospheric puzzle game. It lives from its simple use of ambient light sources and its sound. It's not that hard to beat like other platform games for example Braid.

LIMBO has an awesome and anti frustration auto save game mechanism, where you will never rage quit and still enjoy the game as if you haven't died.

You will not get all achievements in your first run, but you have the option to load each chapter again to get 12 / 14 achievements very fast and easy. The achievement 'DING!' is much fun and challenging. The hardest achievement is 'No Point in Dying', but not impossible.

If you like Indie games especially puzzle games without have a big story in the background, then this is a game for your library.

Recommend!; when it's on sale!, because the main gameplay time is around 3 hours.

reviewText: Ultimately, not what I expected. I normally hate 2D platformers/sidescrollers because of the oversaturated market, but this was actually a good game despite its flaws (which was the inherited overhype). I think what made me respect this game was the excuse for having such a simple artstyle. That gets so abused today, but I liked this. Maybe the simplicity is what makes it what it is? At least the story anyway. The dystopian world could do with more details, but you don't always need details to send a message. Many take a really obvious explanation to the ending, but I like thinking of it much more philosophically; something everyone can relate to sometime in their life. This makes the game so much more powerful, and particularly interesting, and I believe it to be the very best way to enjoy it. Play it by yourself on a lonely evening and ponder about life as a whole. I swear

reviewText:
Limbo is a puzzle platformer game. But at the same time, it is so much more. It is a statement. Thing is, it's up to you to decide what it is saying.
When I first launched the game, I was struck by how it looked. The aesthetic instantly reminded me of old black and white movies. I was blown away by the strange beauty of the place I woke up in. After learning relatively quickly that the game would give me no directions, I learned the controls, which are conveniently all next to each other. You can literally play Limbo with your left arm tied behind your back.
I played forward, breezing through different puzzles, until the spider appeared. Do not play this game if you have extreme arachnophobia. This thing manages to make the spiders in Harry Potter or Eight Legged Freaks look like puppies. Eventually, you will overcome this foe, which will leave you feeling... Strangely sad for it. The people appear only shortly after the spider does, and there's even a little interaction between the two in the form of a human figure impaled on one of the spider's legs.
These people will kill you. Who are they? Why do they want you dead? When you get to the city, why is it so run down? It's post apocalyptic, it seems. Who was doing all the tests towards the end of the game? Why are the arthropods so gigantic?
Limbo does not set out to answer these questions. In fact, it leaves you with more questions than answers. In a way, this is good. You can create a story not just for the little boy you play as, but also for the world he faces, and what he finds at the end. Some might not find this lack of information satisfactory.
There is just as little information in the descriptions for the achievements. Expect to hunt. Do not expect to easily find.
All in all, I like it. No, scratch that, I love it. Through the grim darkness, there seems to be a strange and ironic appreciation of life displayed here. I would definitely reccomend this game to others, and it will sit proudly on my desktop to be replayed many times.

reviewText:
“Indie Puzzle-Platformer” isn’t the most enticing of terms for a PC gamer. It seems like such an accessible kind of game that every bedroom dev and their mother has made one, but that’s only because of games like Limbo. Probably preaching to the choir here but on the assumption that you’ve never heard of this game, I’ll tell you why it’s great.

The mechanics are the standard 2-D side scrolling fare, except your movement speed and jump height feel a little less than other games of the genre. But that really plays into the main selling point of the game, which is the atmosphere. The entire game is in a bleak, high-contrast, black and white and beside some beautiful ambient sounds one might almost call music, the main sounds you’ll here are the ones made by interacting with the environment: Creaking wood or trudging footsteps – sounds normally minimised – are amplified to contribute an atmosphere of I guess “loneliness”. I’m unashamedly in love with this game’s sound design.

Limbo’s release rightly sparked up the “games as art” debate when it was released, and if you experience it for a moment you’ll see why. All the above and more contribute to make you feel things: more than a usual sense of accomplishment or kick of adrenalin (although it has those too). It draws you in and makes you feel lost and powerless, but with a sense of hope spurred on by every small victory over the environment.

Limbo is after all a game about a journey. Where from or to is not readily explained and it doesn’t really matter because the getting there is the experience. Every obstacle you overcome is simple but satisfying because it brings you closer to your goal, even though you have no idea when or where that is. And the journey never gets boring. The moment you get bored of the trudging moving of boxes on foot, the game shakes things up by rotating the screen or giving you a brain slug (no, really).

If you have no patience for trial-and-error gameplay then maybe the puzzles might irritate you a bit. The game will unfairly kill you sometimes, but pick you up right before your death with the knowledge of the oncoming buzzsaw. Also, if you’re expecting an especially long game you’ll be pretty disappointed (unless you SUCK at puzzles). Oh and if you don’t have a wired 360 controller you might fall afoul of imprecise digital keyboard controls.

Negatives done? OK, roundup: Limbo is beautiful, atmospheric and (for me) the right level of challenging. I’d hesitate to call it perfect except that I can’t think of anything I’d change, but then I’m not a developer.

reviewText: Imagine yourself walking in a forest one night. Dark, desolated, alone. You walked on, without the faintest idea of where you are heading. The forest is empty apart from the vague shadows of the leaves falling. A soft, obscured sound taps you on your shoulder.  You turned around, in hope of finding someone, something, that you can share your woes with. But no, that did not happen. All that stood in front of you are pillars and pillars of trees, looming, casting their ominous shadows onto you. You yelled, you screamed, and you cried, praying that a being, any being, will answer to your call. This is all to no avail. You have no choice but to venture on. However, deep down inside you, you know very well that someone is here, someone is listening to your calls, and that someone does not want you to be where you are. Welcome to Limbo.\n\nLimbo is nothing more than the silhouette of a world where the protagonist venture on in desolating loneliness. Using simple controls, you will have to interact with the surroundings as the story unfolds while making sure that the protagonist lives. It's not an easy task, as everything out there wants you gone. Fellow humans, giant spiders, rocks, pipes, blades, clockworks, everything. Well, you might think that, with only two colours, this game is easy, right? Think twice, as when the colours are so monotonous, you are bound to miss something that is out to get you.

reviewText:
The name Limbo is an honest introduction to this game as a whole.

Like limbo, for its duration the game is enigmatic, undefinable, and otherworldly with black and white graphics and a film grain, everything in the game animated as black silhouettes against a dreary, lonely backdrop made of shifting shades of gray. It has minimalist but effective sound design, think drippy water and receding footsteps, or a few flies buzzing at you. It's not full on horror, but it's a beautiful and perfect feeling of dread, wandering and isolation, all quite poetic, which is why critics just sweet talked the pants off of it and made sweet love to it in their reviews.

You'll like it mostly for these one-of-a-kind aesthetics more than for its pretty standard puzzle platforming - you might be disappointed if you are a 'gameplay first' type of hardcore indie gamer. The puzzles all come in the form of risky or deadly traps or mysterious enemies that you have to somehow negotiate or kill. This is as close as the game ever comes to horrific, with some panic of imminent death punctuating the usual thick melancholy.

If you want a short, sweet game that, if played in a dark room with headphones will really suck you in, it's definitely worth it for half or 75% off (I grabbed it for $2.50). Expect to seriously use your imagination every few levels, because though there aren't many parts to the puzzles, their solutions are not always apparent, and this adds to the game's enigmatic feeling. Plenty of puzzles you just have to die through several times to understand, but there are a ton of checkpoints, and this trial and error is intended, so don't let it get to you.

Now that I think of it, it makes sense that the development team is Danish. Its sensibility of *bleh* is very cold, very pretty, and very Scandinavian.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Limbo is probably the best puzzle / reflection game I've played.

First because of it's unique atmosphere, creepy and disturbing. That dark world (I don't even think there's any colour in the whole game excepted from blackness and light) is worse than hell. The death animations of that little boy will make you shudder every single time.
The story behind all this isn't explained... you just wake up in there and can make suppositions with the scenario according to the very ending.
On the gameplay side it's simply perfect. The level of difficulty is not too easy, not too hard, its just complicated. And it gets really harder when you want to get the different secrets hidden, you really need to look out for each single detail and try random things to get to them.

Get that game ! :p

reviewText: Imagine yourself walking in a forest one night. Dark, desolated, alone. You walked on, without the faintest idea of where you are heading. The forest is empty apart from the vague shadows of the leaves falling. A soft, obscured sound taps you on your shoulder.  You turned around, in hope of finding someone, something, that you can share your woes with. But no, that did not happen. All that stood in front of you are pillars and pillars of trees, looming, casting their ominous shadows onto you. You yelled, you screamed, and you cried, praying that a being, any being, will answer to your call. This is all to no avail. You have no choice but to venture on. However, deep down inside you, you know very well that someone is here, someone is listening to your calls, and that someone does not want you to be where you are. Welcome to Limbo.\n\nLimbo is nothing more than the silhouette of a world where the protagonist venture on in desolating loneliness. Using simple controls, you will have to interact with the surroundings as the story unfolds while making sure that the protagonist lives. It's not an easy task, as everything out there wants you gone. Fellow humans, giant spiders, rocks, pipes, blades, clockworks, everything. Well, you might think that, with only two colours, this game is easy, right? Think twice, as when the colours are so monotonous, you are bound to miss something that is out to get you.

reviewText:
Brought to you by the minds at Playdead, LIMBO is a bleak puzzle-platforming title that follows the bizarre trials of an unnamed adolescent as he journeys through perilous territories. Though the boy is simplistically presented, portraying no characteristics of audio cues, and the puzzles require much experimentation to achieve completion, the story it has to tell is engaging, as the protagonist perils through increasingly difficult struggles that occur subsequent to each other in a search for his lost sister.
Here are a few items that I enjoyed about LIMBO:

Gameplay - LIMBO holds a striking comparison to other Indie titles when it comes to the control layout: it is entirely straightforward. As you may or may not have experienced in prior games, this title utilizes the directional keys for basic movement-with down allowing your character to drop down and grab onto a ledge-, the Space Bar to jump, and the Control key to interact with objects and the environment itself; others have stated that this is much more fluid while playing with a plug-in controller. This painless layout aides the player in not forcing them to have to remember too many needless actions; if the controls could be remapped, a player could even be able to play it with one hand. In summary, the controls are of simple design for a simple game. As described previously-without revealing too much in terms of story progression-the player directs the young boy through treacherous territories, which prompts the solving of intricate puzzles. These stages-numbering twenty-four in total-generally require the player to test the mechanics in a ‘truth and error’ approach, unless applied thought is given to the situation for a considerable amount of time prior to action. A decent reaction time is necessary for certain portions since platforming is included into the general mechanics, which can be somewhat frustrating and rewarding due to the intense precision specific stages necessitate.

Atmosphere - LIMBO is very black and white in terms of its color palette in that it is literally variants of black and white (if you have read my previous reviews, you know that I am not permitted to make jokes due to the overall lack of comedy involved, hence this current display.) This helps to depict the grim depth of this title’s occurrences, as well as developing tone that is not distracting from the gameplay. Even the game’s playstyle is murky since the protagonist’s death is intended to remind the player what they had done wrong in a specific segment and as an indication of how the level’s mechanics are set. The game shifts seamlessly between transition periods with minimal loading and intractable events. Hence the end of the game, which directly transfers into the beginning and causes the player to feel as though the protagonist’s ordeals are hopeless. Throughout, however, you may just become attached to said protagonist as though his struggles become your very own. The protagonist portrays no vocal characteristics, though the background effects add enough ambience to compensate for this.

TL:DR - For those with keen senses in regards to game mechanics, you will find LIMBO to be trivial yet enjoyable. This title is a deep, brooding tale with no words and only atmosphere to speak its demented thoughts. It is a relatively short title that can be frustrating at times but is worth its cost as an experience. Though the protagonist does not and cannot outwardly portray his ideals, you will surely fight for him to learn of his sister’s fate. You will learn much as a player and an adventurer, but do not lose hope in LIMBO. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

reviewText:
There has been much written about heaven and hell. The absolute paradise of the former and the absolute pain of the latter are some of only a small handful of human ideas that are immune to hyperbole; our mortal descriptions of such places will never be too much and of that we can be sure.

But what about what lies between? The concept of purgatory is a much harder one to pin down. Thoughts on the concept, both lay and philosophical, have defined it as anything from a second mortal existence to an afterlife of absolute nothingness. If the title is to be believed, LIMBO ostensibly takes place in this in-between afterlife. It may not be hell, but it is a far cry from heaven.

Uncertain of his sister's fate
date: a boy enters LIMBO." This lone sentence is the closest thing to a synopsis that the creators have given us. How the boy got to limbo is unclear. Why you must press forward is unclear. But to stand still is to both promise and condemn yourself to nothing.\n\nBut after all
recommended: LIMBO is a puzzle platformer and the instinct to move forward is natural. The puzzles are elegantly designed and make the most of your limited capability for interaction: running
hoursPlayed: jumping
voteText: and moving objects. Everything feels right and the game plays as a good platformer should.\n\nLIMBO is not content to only be another decent indie platformer
votesHelpful: as the puzzles very quickly become trials of dread and fear. Death has always been part of platformers
votesTotal: but LIMBO is almost eager to remind you of the pain. In your desire to move forward
votesFunny: you only introduce to your character more ways to die. If you miss that jump
commentsCount: you will fall down a pit and be impaled on the spikes below. You will have your body torn to pieces by the crushing force of a giant bear trap. You will fall into a ragdoll's seizure as electricity fries you. Even the more quiet deaths feel horrible; drowning in water is a whole process of struggling and sinking before becoming still. The screen will linger and you will sit with it until you are ready to press a button to respawn. Do you want to try again?\n\nThe hazards of LIMBO seem too much to all be manmade
column16: but they all seem purposeful. It is hard to ignore the sense of malice that pervades this world. The colorless settings and the silhouetted character designs do some amount in making the deaths less gruesome
column17: but only so much. You might find yourself standing still when you get that second chance. To stand still is to do nothing
column18: but to move forward is to create your own hell.\n\nBut maybe you do keep pushing forward and maybe you do succeed more often than you fail. The purpose of this boy's search for his sister is unclear: it could be a journey of redemption
column21: that there is even a chance at success and a chance at relief at the other end of each dangerous trial is
column23: a promise of heaven. There will be hard times ahead
column24: but the pain is not infinite. To be given the chance to find an answer and reach an end is a small but merciful thing. But before that
column25: the hard times will only get harder.\n\nThere will always be ideas about what lies between heaven and hell
column26: life and death. LIMBO has earned its spot among the best artistic representations of such a place – not only through its undeniable dark beauty
column27: but also the fear that a similar world might await us."

reviewText:
Short version: 71%Limbo has a catchy art design and an interesting, depressing atmosphere. Sadly those are the only real selling points of this otherwise quite generic puzzle platformer.

Long version:Limbo is all about style: a noir-like, minimalist, but nonetheless unique art style. If you wouldn’t mind staring at what you see in the preview screenshots for 2-4 hours, then Limbo will definitely be your game. And it knows how important first expressions are, because the initial atmosphere is superb, the eerie forest sets a very memorable tone.

Still, it is mostly just a façade. A façade that hides a fairly generic puzzle platformer set in the most overused and tired settings for such games, a boring factory. A façade that tries to hide the fact that the game has no story: all you do is walk right and try to get past various obstacles that prevent you from walking right.

As for puzzle mechanics, there are a few clever ones, like a parasite that makes you unable to stop moving in one direction (usually towards a pit), or some gravity manipulation. They are too rare though in the endless sea of uninspired box and switch puzzles. And they aren’t even difficult puzzles; the difficulty comes from trying to implement the easy solutions with incredibly tight timing and jumps. You’re gonna die. A lot. (©LordKat)

If puzzle platformers are your thing, by all means, get it. Despite my musings, it is one of the better ones to come out in these years. Just don’t have too high expectations for it.

reviewText:
Unfortunately, a beautiful art style and atmosphere is all this game has going for it. The puzzles are tedious and unintuitive (eg. One puzzle is solved by luring some creature out of a hole with food and then chasing that creature to a giant hamster wheel. This, for some reason, triggers a hurricane and fills a hole with water for you cross over on top of a log...). Many of the puzzles require precison timing, which would be fine if the character wasn't restrictively and frustratingly slow.

+ Nice art style
+ Good use of atmosphere
+ Simple and fluid controls

- Overall tedious and bland gameplay
- Puzzles are more difficult to complete due to restrictive game mechanics (speed, physics) than actual complexity

I actually think I would enjoy this game more if all the puzzles were removed and the focus was solely on the atmosphere, because walking and exploring were more fun for me than actually doing the puzzles.

reviewText:
For what it is, I can't find a true fault with LIMBO.

The game doesn't claim to be anything it isn't, it's a simple puzzle/sidescrolling game that will at times leave you frustrated and put out, only to experience that giddiness of figuring it out shortly thereafter. It never traipses about claiming to be anything more than it is. For lack of the ingenuity to phrase it better, they whole-♥♥♥♥♥ what they envisioned, and left the rest by the wayside.

The plot is vague, so secondary it might as well not exist... and I'm quite alright with that in this case. You are tossed into a bleak, unforgiving, and cruelly beautiful world to... move to the right (and die quite a few times on your way). Might not seem like much, but it's stunning and worth every minute.

Obligatory mention that Martin Stig Andersen's work on this only reinforces my mild to manic obsession with well done soundtracks. Phenomenally moody, reminiscent of quite a bit of John Luther Adams' work. I can't imagine anything more fitting.

A small part that I particularly enjoyed are that the achievements... are actually achievements. It doesn't throw you one every time you remember to blink or jump for the first time.

Wonderful game.

reviewText: While it only took me 3.4 hours to beat, those 3.4 hours were some of the best I have had in my gaming history. Lately, indie titles like Braid, Trine, Limbo and others have been some of my favorite games overall. Not only does Limbo have amazing puzzle solving gameplay but it also has a... I feel weird saying this... a very touching storyline. Also, for a game with no writen or spoken words, Limbo has possibly the greatest atmosphere of any game (only competition would be S.T.A.L.K.E.R.) and it never gets old. I hope to God there is a sequel to this game, either way, I cannot wait to play the next game from developer Playdead, and please do yourself a favor and experience this game.\n\n5/5

reviewText:
LIMBO, a black and white puzzle-platforming adventure, puts players in the role of a young boy traveling through an eerie and treacherous world in an attempt to discover the fate of his sister.

'LIMBO is a wonderfully dark experience with its only real flaw being its stunted length.'

'Limbo will assault your senses and challenge your intellect with one of the best puzzle-adventure games I've ever played on any system.'

'A beautifully designed masterpiece of a platform game, that will chill, challenge and charm in equal measure.'

'It immerses players almost effortlessly thanks to its sleek design and delightfully subtle lighting effects and creepy-looking shadows.'

'Melancholic yet thrilling adventure you play over all at once. Game of clever puzzles and stylish visuals did not lose any of its appeal since its first appearance on consoles.'

reviewText: Welcome to the horrid world between Death & Shadow. LIMBO.  You play as a small unnamed boy who first finds himself waking in the middle of a dark and gloomy forest.  In this 2 D scroller you’ll traverse what appears to be a dead forest and a ruined ancient city. Along the way you’ll encounter some people, small animals and deadly Monster type enemies that will either try to kill you or control you. If this doesn’t finish you off the elaborate death puzzles will. The game is played in Black and White and is lite by various lighting sources. There are some achievements to discover and you’ll soon be captivated by the angst of one small boy in search of his kid Sister. You can finish this game in about 4 to 6 hours and it does have it’s replay value as you’ll probably miss some awards the first time around. If you have an appetite for Morbid darkness, this will add some flavor to your diet.

reviewText: Limbo is an extremely dark puzzle-adventure game. The game is hilariously sick, creating an atmosphere easily meant for older crowds, despite the childish appearance of the game. The graphics and rendering are amazing and beautifully crafted. The puzzles start easy and increase in difficulty at an even pace, building up in darkness as well as becoming more challenging. The game forces the player to pay close attention and really think of what they have to do. The only downside to the game is how relatively short the gameplay is. After only a few extremely short hours, one reaches the end of the game. While the game itself is interesting and fun, the shortness creates an overall sense of one being unfufilled. Unless, the player is someone who enjoys a quick and challenging game. Any sequals or exstensions for the game would be greatly anticipated.\nFun 4/5, Originality 4/5, Mature 4/5, Graphics 5/5, Addictive 2/5, Repetative 2/5, Worth the Price 3/5

reviewText:
Limbo is a 2D platform game where you play a nameless boy who wakes up in a dark forest and needs to find his way past obstacles while looking for his sister.
At the start, the visual art was sort of reminiscent of late 20th century Eastern European animated kids movies. But the dark environment quickly escalates into horrific scenes with severed limbs and other terror to be found in the woods... Not a game for kids!
I found myself quickly drawn into the atmosphere solving puzzle by puzzle. Most of them are fairly straightforward and logical, others require trial & error or some more thinking. The controls are easy and won't break your fingers.
Overall, a highly recommended puzzle game! But beware of the spiders...

Score: 8.5/10

Pro:
+ immersive graphics
+ balanced mix of puzzles

Contra:
- maybe a bit too short?

reviewText: One of the most interesting indie games that I have played. The beautiful graphics, interesting locales, and lonesome soundtrack combine to create an incredibly eerie atmosphere. reviewText: The game loads.  There is no intro.  Your character wakes up.  Where do you go? What do you do? The game is very atmospheric and the different shades of grey work amazingly well. reviewText:
Pros:
- very fun physics-based puzzles
- frequent checkpoints
- unique & interesting visual style
- dark & creepy atmosphere
- good sense of isolation & exploration
- good ambient sound effects
- gruesome death animations
- secret hidden eggs & bonus area w/ difficult challenge

Cons:
- short game
- very little replayability
- no volume control, sparse options
- can't customize controls
- gamepad support limited to Xbox360 controller only

Other Thoughts:
Don't expect to get more than 10 hours tops out of this game. In spite of that I would highly recommend LIMBO if you like games that involve thought-provoking puzzles, simply because the experience is that AWESOME while it lasts. The lack of options is a minor issue & doesn't really impact the enjoyment of the game itself.

-- read the FULL REVIEW at http://www.metacritic.com/user/Shad0WeN --

reviewText:
From what I can gather of a premise, we play as a boy, lost in as the title suggests, Limbo trying to find his sister.

StoryHonestly, unless you can read inbetween the lines that is inbetween that, I find the story is extremely vague and left up to interpretation.  I actually looked it up and maybe the one guy I found who figured it out pulled it out of some nether region I'll never fully know, but it somewhat makes sense.  Point being, there is no narrative, the story speaks through what environments and little cutscenes you see but otherwise you are left to your own conclusion as to what is going on.

GraphicsNot that story matters when the game looks this pretty, or morbid depending on how you look at it.  It uses a Noir inspired aesthetic with fluid sprites and movement.  Grass sways, boxes make crack a bit under the weight of your character, lighting also plays a big role in the game setting tone.  Your character also has a tendency to look around and move his hands (more as a hint when a puzzle clue is near) and it's so fluid and lovely to behold.

Gameplay/ControlsI put both categories in here since I felt given the nature of how this game actually is, felt are one in the same.  You solve puzzles, you use fancy buttons to solve puzzles.  The problem is the puzzles cause you to die repeatedly, and there is absolutely no way you can prevent your death in some cases on your first (or third try) due to the fact that simply jumping over say what looks to be a dangerous hazard actually wasn't dangerous, the thing you landed on upon jumping over it was the real hazard.  Assuming your guy even jumps or decides to jump to early.  For some reason they decided to map the jump button to the up arrow key, and there is no way to remap it, no controller support, nothing.  So you will accidentally jump off of a box trying to climb on top of it due to overly twitchy controls.  Add in trollish puzzles that just outright kill you for no apparent reason other then the fact you are a noob and don't have the thing perfectly memorized is rather unforgivable for a puzzle game.  There are hard puzzles, there are puzzles that punish mistakes but never should a puzzle kill you for just trying to be cautious for kicks.

SoundAs far as the music goes, it relies on ambience instead of outright scary" music.  Most of the time you are hearing whatever level's background noise would be prevelent (wind brushing through the trees for example) minus a few areas where the ambience does kick up and leave you unnerved.

ConclusionWhile the game is pretty
recommended: I don't recommend it unless you are a glutton for punishment.  The Demo of this game is actually what the rest of the game should've been
hoursPlayed: however once you buy the game and are past that it all goes downhill very fast and you don't give a crap about anything then just wanting to finish it and never have to play it again."

reviewText:
This is one of those games that has sat in my Steam library for years in the 'Another Artsy Indie Game I'll Try Someday' category.

And now I wish I had tried it sooner.

The first time your character gets decapitated by a bear trap, you will feel a tingle up your spine. When the spider catches you and spins you into its web, you will shudder with revulsion. When you finally (and brutally) tear the final leg from the spider's  body, you will marvel at how satisfying such a gruesome act could be.

And all this is after just 48 minutes of playing the game! Any game that can tap my emotions so deftly will earn a resounding recommendation from me, regarless of how good/bad/ugly those emotions happen to be. Bonus points for acheiving this feat in such a minimalist environment with no vocals/text or any other in-game guidance (other than said environment itself).

Final thought: I don't enjoy horror games. While this game has caused me to feel terror, I don't clasify it as 'horror'. This game is not violent or scary for the sake of being violent/scary, but uses the induced emotional state as a mechanic within the game (although you may not realize this at first).

Duly recommended.

reviewText:
So i did not like this game and did not finish it. I usually like puzzle platformers but this one got me so frustrated a rage quit after an hour.

The puzzles are not very hard but they require timing. Also for many puzzles you have to die at least once to know what to do because they are not logical at all when you just get some random black and white objects. The timed puzzles are terrible. The character is slow and cannot jump very high so timing stuff is not easy.

Furthermore, the art style is probably supposed to be cool and original but i was not impressed.

The one thing that sometimes keeps me going through games like this is the story, which is non-existent. Yes i know i did not finish but the game should introduce the character, why the hell am i doing all this stuff and where. Instead you are thrown in the world, no explanations about anything or anyone, i have no clue why i should want to finish this game.
Maybe it is me, i am stupid for not understanding or something but i just hated it.

In my opinion not worth the money, thankfully i got it in a bundle.

reviewText: One of the best games I have ever played. It shares a lot of design principles and features of the Half-Life series. Like Half-Life, there is a silent protagonist and no narration but subtle hints of what to do next are presented. It's dark, it's ambiently dynamic, and it doesn't tell a story but shows the player instead. The game is a mix of physics-based puzzles and action sequences. It will genuinely scare you and give you adrenaline rushes. It will get in your head and use psychology against you. Prepare to die many times in gruesome and dramatic fashions but it helps make a 5-hour game feel much longer.

reviewText:
Game: LIMBO
Genre: Puzzle
Developer: PLAYDEAD
System: Steam (PC)
Total Score: 74/100
Value Score: 7.4/10

• Story: 6/10
• Characters: 6/10
• GamePlay: 10/10
• Graphics: 8/10
• Sound: 10/10
• Music: 4/10
• Length: 5/10
• Replay Value: 8/10
• Player Value: 7/10

Pros
+Great Puzzles
+Gameplay focused mostly on dark colors and sound effects which bring a unique experience.
+Great for those who love difficult games as the game can be brutal.
+Great for horror fans
+Great for casual fans and those who want to play something short and sweet.
+Replay value is high as you can replay every single section even if you want to play certain stages or if you missed some achievements, the game allows you to go back exactly to a specific part rather than playing the game all over again.

Cons
-No Plot or character development however it is up to the player's imagination to decrypt on what the game is about.
-Very little to no music used at all.
-Length might not be suitable for some people who are looking for a long term experience.
-Game can become quite difficult through its puzzles and traps.

reviewText: LIMBO, where do I start with this game?\nYou play as a young boy going through LIMBO (place between heaven and hell) to find his sister. He doesn't even know if she's alive. As you go through LIMBO you go through hard puzzles and through dark eery places. The boy you play as, goes through of what I think is his life. Forest being his child-hood, Hotel is his teenage age and Industrial as his adult hood. Overall this game has a great story. Ending may be confusing for some people, but if you take the time to think what is happening and what you're doing throughout the story, you will get this game.\nMY RATING ----> 4.5/5 ~Great story, Great gameplay, Would highly replay.
